title: Deadly Cholera Outbreak in Sudan Claims 40 Lives, MSF Warns of Worsening Crisis
snippets: MSF says displacement, war and rain driving deadly cholera outbreak in Sudan as infections continue to mount.

The humanitarian organization described this as the worst cholera outbreak Sudan has seen in years. The situation is especially dire in the Darfur region, where clean water is scarce amid the fighting.

MSF charity calls situation ‘beyond urgent’ as thousands seeking refuge from war rely on contaminated water

The “worst cholera outbreak in years” has killed at least 40 people in the last week in Sudan, according to the medical charity Médecins Sans Frontières.

Overwhelmed medical cen
International charities warned that, left unchecked, the disease’s spread might exacerbate similar outbreaks across the African region for weeks or months to come.
titles: Cholera kills 40 as Sudan faces worst outbreak in years, says MSF
MSF says Sudan war fueling deadly cholera outbreak
Sudan cholera outbreak kills 40 in a week as health centres overwhelmed
Sudan Hit by Its ‘Worst Cholera Outbreak’ in Years, Medical Charity Says
summary: A deadly cholera outbreak in Sudan, described as the worst in years by Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), has resulted in at least 40 deaths in the last week. Factors such as displacement, war, and heavy rain, particularly in the Darfur region, have exacerbated the situation by limiting access to clean water. MSF has highlighted the urgency of the crisis as thousands depend on contaminated water sources. International charities have expressed concern that without intervention, the outbreak could worsen and spread across the African region for an extended period.

The charges stem from an incident in May, where Doyle is accused of intentionally driving his car into a crowd celebrating Liverpool's Premier League title win.

Russian President Vladimir Putin on Thursday praised President Donald Trump for his efforts to broker an end to Moscow's invasion of Ukraine.
Russian president’s comments come ahead of high-stakes Alaska summit that has been criticised for excluding Kyiv

This praise was given in the context of the upcoming high-stakes summit in Alaska, which has faced criticism for not including Kyiv in the discussions.

title: PSG Wins UEFA Super Cup, Defeats Tottenham on Penalties
snippets: French forward Mathys Tel was one of two Tottenham players to miss their penalties in the UEFA Super Cup defeat by PSG.
Tottenham's late collapse saw them blow a 2-0 UEFA Super Cup lead with five minutes to play as Paris Saint-Germain snatched the first European trophy of the season on penalties in Udine.
Tottenham has slammed the “cowards” who racially abused French forward Mathys Tel after the team’s loss to Paris Saint-Germain in the UEFA Super Cup after a penalty shootout.
titles: Tottenham slam racist abuse of Tel after defeat by PSG in UEFA Super Cup
Tottenham heartbreak as PSG win Super Cup on penalties after late collapse
Tottenham condemns racist abuse of Mathys Tel after UEFA Super Cup
summary: Paris Saint-Germain secured the UEFA Super Cup title after a remarkable comeback against Tottenham Hotspur, ending the match 2-2 in regular time and winning 4-3 on penalties. The game, held in Udine, saw PSG score two late goals to force a shootout, ultimately claiming their first European trophy of the season and their fifth trophy of 2025.

title: South Korea Court Rules "Baby Shark" Not Plagiarized
snippets: The catchy tune known for its "doo doo doo doo doo doo" hook was not plagiarized, the court ruled.

Ruling upheld that there was insufficient evidence of copyright infringement on song that is YouTube’s most viewed video

South Korea’s supreme court has rejected a US composer’s allegation that the producers of the catchy children’s song Baby Shark plagiarised his work, ending a six-year-lo
The judges found “Baby Shark” was based on a nursery rhyme, dismissing the six-year case of U.S. entertainer Johnny Only that centered on his 2011 version.
titles: South Korea's top court rejects 'Baby Shark' copyright claim
Baby Shark: South Korean court rejects US composer’s claim song was plagiarised
Top South Korean court listens to ‘Baby Shark,’ rejects copyright suit
summary: South Korea's Supreme Court upheld a ruling that the children's song "Baby Shark," known for its "doo doo doo doo doo doo" hook and being YouTube’s most viewed video, was not plagiarized. This decision came after a US composer's copyright claim was rejected due to insufficient evidence of copyright infringement.

title: Wayne Rooney Responds to Tom Brady's Criticism on Work Ethic

Former England captain Wayne Rooney says it was "very unfair" of NFL great Tom Brady to question his work ethic as manager at Birmingham City.

Rooney described Brady's comments, which were made in a documentary, as "very unfair." The dispute highlights a rare public disagreement between two high-profile athletes from different sports.

title: Court Rules NFL to Face Trial in Discrimination Claims
snippets: The NFL can be put on trial over civil claims that Brian Flores and other Black coaches face discrimination, a federal appeals court ruled Thursday.
The court found insurmountable flaws with the NFL's arbitration process
titles: Court agrees Flores' suit vs. NFL can go to trial

title: NCAA Extends College Basketball Season to 32 Games from 2026-27
snippets: Pope also gave a full offseason update on the Wildcats in advance of Year 2 on Thursday's Eye on College Basketball podcast

Just two months ago, the NCAA voted to increase the college basketball regular season from 31 games to 32 games beginning in the 2026-27 season. This was done to encourage more high-profile non-conference games and multi-team events, such as the Maui Invitational, the Players Era Tournament and the
titles: Kentucky's Mark Pope wants 40-game regular season, portal opening moved to after NCAA Tournament
Mark Pope endorses 40-game regular season in college basketball
summary: The NCAA has decided to extend the college basketball regular season from 31 to 32 games starting in the 2026-27 season. This change aims to promote more high-profile non-conference matchups and participation in multi-team events like the Maui Invitational. Additionally, Pope provided a comprehensive offseason update on the Wildcats ahead of their second year on the Eye on College Basketball podcast.

title: Trump Rates Call with EU Leaders on Ukraine "a Ten," Vows to Prioritize Kyiv
snippets: The Russian leader senses a chance for more international recognition, while his American counterpart hopes to play peacemaker.

European leaders said a call with President Donald Trump was unifying and that he agreed Ukraine should be part of any negotiations over territory, but some still worry he could give in to Russian President Vladimir Putin.
titles: What do Putin and Trump each want from summit in Alaska?
Europeans, Zelensky cite unity with Trump ahead of Putin summit in Alaska
summary: President Trump described his call with European leaders about Ukraine as "a ten" and agreed that Ukraine's interests should be prioritized in his upcoming meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin. Despite the unifying tone of the call, there are concerns among some European leaders that Trump might concede to Putin's demands in negotiations over territory.

title: July Producer Price Index Rises, Matches Dow Jones Forecast

titles: Wholesale prices rose 0.9% in July, much more than expected

summary: In July, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported an increase in the producer price index, indicating that prices for wholesale goods and services rose. This outcome aligns with the Dow Jones consensus estimate, which had anticipated a 0.2% increase for the month.

title: Apple Drops Blood Oxygen Sensor in US Watches After Patent Ruling
snippets: In 2023, the International Trade Commission found that Apple's blood oxygen sensors infringed on intellectual property from Masimo.
Feature had been removed from US Apple Watches after Apple lost a patent fight.
titles: Apple Watch getting redesigned blood oxygen feature following legal dispute
Apple Watch gets reformulated, non-patent-infringing blood oxygen monitoring
summary: In 2023, the International Trade Commission determined that Apple's blood oxygen sensors violated Masimo's intellectual property. As a result, Apple removed this feature from its US watches following a patent dispute.

title: Israel Approves 3,401 New Homes in West Bank, Stirring Controversy
snippets: Far-right Israeli minister Bezalel Smotrich announced approval for 3,401 new homes in the controversial E1 area project in the occupied West Bank.
Israel's far-right finance minister has approved plans for thousands of illegal homes in the occupied West Bank.
titles: Israeli settlement plans will 'bury' idea of Palestinian state, minister says
Israel approves settlement expansion to “bury idea of Palestinian state”
summary: Bezalel Smotrich, Israel's far-right finance minister, has approved the construction of 3,401 new homes in the E1 area of the occupied West Bank, a move that has sparked controversy. This area is considered by many as key to the territorial continuity of a future Palestinian state, and the international community generally views all Israeli settlements in the West Bank as illegal.

title: New DNA Repair Pathway Discovered in Human Cells
snippets: A research team has successfully identified a novel DNA damage repair pathway in human cells. This study is the first to discover that proteins present in the nuclear membrane of cells directly interact with damaged DNA, forming part of a signaling pathway that helps repair DNA.
titles: Human cells reveal a novel DNA damage repair pathway
summary: A research team discovered a new DNA damage repair pathway in human cells, revealing that proteins in the cell's nuclear membrane interact with damaged DNA to aid in its repair. This marks the first identification of such a process, highlighting a significant advancement in understanding cellular repair mechanisms.

title: "Study Highlights Key Role of miRNAs in Gene Regulation Across Biology"
snippets: MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are tiny RNA molecules that regulate gene expression by controlling messenger RNAs (mRNAs) and are critical for various biological processes, including development, stress responses, and epigenetic regulation. In plants, the enzyme DICER-LIKE 1 (DCL1) processes miRNA precursors in
titles: GHR motif discovery reveals new mechanism in plant miRNA processing
summary: MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are small RNA molecules essential for regulating gene expression by managing messenger RNAs (mRNAs). These miRNAs play a crucial role in numerous biological functions, such as development, stress responses, and epigenetic regulation. In plants, the enzyme DICER-LIKE 1 (DCL1) is responsible for processing miRNA precursors, highlighting the importance of miRNAs in both plant and animal biology.

title: Ecuador Study Shows 1,500-Year Human Impact on Amazon Ecology
snippets: The inhabitants of the "Lost City of the Amazon" in Ecuador's Upano River Valley grew corn and planted alder trees for over 1,200 years, but a later occupation that lasted just 300 years was the one that changed the ecology of the forest.
titles: Ecuador's 'Lost city of the Amazon': New paper reveals its changing landscapes
summary: Archaeological research in Ecuador's Upano River Valley reveals that the inhabitants of the "Lost City of the Amazon" cultivated corn and alder trees for over 1,200 years. However, a subsequent occupation lasting 300 years significantly altered the forest's ecology. This finding highlights the long-term human impact on the Amazon's environment.

title: MIT AI Develops Antibiotics for Drug-Resistant Infections
snippets: With help from artificial intelligence, MIT researchers have designed novel antibiotics that can combat two hard-to-treat infections: drug-resistant Neisseria gonorrhoeae and multi-drug-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA).
titles: Generative AI designs compounds that can kill drug-resistant bacteria
summary: MIT researchers, utilizing artificial intelligence, have developed new antibiotics effective against two challenging infections: drug-resistant Neisseria gonorrhoeae and multi-drug-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). This advancement marks a significant step in combating antibiotic resistance.

title: Worm Found to Deactivate Human Pain Sensors, May Aid Treatment Development
titles: This Parasitic Worm Can Turn Off Your Pain and Itch Sensors
summary: Researchers have discovered that a specific parasitic worm has the ability to deactivate human pain and itch sensors. This finding, detailed in a study, could have significant implications for developing new pain relief treatments. The study focuses on the mechanisms by which the worm manipulates the human nervous system to achieve this effect, potentially opening up avenues for novel therapeutic strategies.

title: Robotic Missions to Probe Mars, Moon Lava Tubes for Life, Base Sites
snippets: In the not-too-distant future, the search for signs of life on Mars and the moon could see the next generation of robots exploring a new frontier: subsurface lava tubes. These missions could also help us determine the best locations for establishing human bases.
titles: Robots team up to explore planetary lava caves
summary: Future robotic missions may explore subsurface lava tubes on Mars and the moon to search for signs of life and assess potential sites for human bases. This new exploration frontier aims to understand the subsurface environments of these celestial bodies better.

title: NTU Singapore Team Develops Ultracompact, Energy-Efficient Laser
snippets: An international team of scientists led by Nanyang Technological University, Singapore (NTU Singapore) has developed a new type of ultracompact laser that is more energy efficient and consumes less power.
titles: Energy-efficient ultracompact laser reduces light loss in all directions
summary: An international team led by NTU Singapore has created a new, ultracompact laser that is more energy-efficient and uses less power. This advancement in laser technology promises to enhance various applications by providing a more sustainable and cost-effective option.

title: First-Ever Poincaré Light Beam Produced Using FERMI Laser
snippets: A team led by scientists at the Department of Energy's SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory have generated a highly exotic type of light beam, called a Poincaré beam, using the FERMI free-electron laser (FEL) facility in Italy, marking the first time such a beam has been produced with a FEL.
titles: Laser advance sets the stage for new X-ray science possibilities
summary: Scientists at the Department of Energy's SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory have successfully produced a Poincaré beam, an exotic type of light beam, for the first time using the FERMI free-electron laser facility in Italy. This achievement marks a significant advancement in the field of laser technology.
